IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: To conserve Maine's wildlife and wildlife habitat.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Maine Audubon works to conserve Maine's wildlife and habitat by engaging people of all ages in education, conservation, and action. We are helping the people of Maine become the nation's most informed and effective stewards of wildlife and habitat.
IRS990.Desc: Education: Maine Audubon's education programs are designed to increase public environmental literacy and to impel actions such as stewardship, community science, and advocacy on behalf of Maine's wildlife and wildlife habitat. (Please see Schedule O for more detail).

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Conservation: conservation programs are designed to help protect both common and at-risk native wildlife species and habitats in Maine. (Please see Schedule O for more detail).

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Advocacy: our advocacy program works closely with our conservation programs to promote and defend laws, rules, and policies that help conserve native Maine wildlife, with a focus on issues related to our primary projects. (Please see Schedule O for more detail).

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The organization is committed to protect the conservation purpose of the easements. We monitor the use and condition of the restricted property, through onsite inspections, to ensure the property owner is adhering to the imposed restrictions and that the purpose of the easement is being achieved. If we discover violations related to an easement, we will work with the property owner to make necessary corrections and will also employ arbitration and litigation if deemed necessary.

The organization's restricted endowment funds will be used consistent with the wishes of donors who have made restricted gifts, The organization's restricted endowment funds will be used at the discretion of the Board of Trustees in furthering the organization's mission.

The Organization has adopted the provisions of FASB ASC, Income Taxes. Management of the Organization believes it has no material uncertain tax positions and, accordingly it will not recognize any liability for unrecognized tax benefits.
Cost of Goods Sold Netted with Revenue 156,419. Rental Expenses Netted with Revenue 58,024.
Cost of Goods Sold Netted with Revenue 156,419. Rental Expenses Netted with Revenue 58,024.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part III, Line 1, Description for Organization Mission
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Maine Audubon is comprised of seven regional chapters and eight wildlife sanctuaries. Year-round conservation education programming takes place at two centers, and seasonal programming at two other sanctuaries. Maine Audubon has 10,000 members and serves over 100,000 people of all ages annually via programs, outreach, and visits to our sanctuaries. Our programs are divided into three main areas - education, conservation, and advocacy. We work with many communities and stakeholders to conserve threatened and endangered species; improve stewardship and habitat connectivity; lead community science projects; increase environmental literacy; and support policies and legislation that protect wildlife and wildlife habitat.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part III, Line 4a, Program Service Accomplishments
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: EDUCATION- Our primary statewide education activities and areas of focus include: (1) conducting outreach programs to prekindergartens and schools; (2) hosting and leading field trips and in-depth units of study with schools and other learning communities; (3) family programs and events; (4) naturalist-led walks, talks, and field trips programs for adults; (5) chartering guided boat trips for seeing and learning about seabirds; (6) outreach programs, social media campaigns, and events to promote community science and stewardship priorities; (7) professional development programs for teachers and community leaders; (8) canoe and kayak rentals and guided trips; (9) camp programs for youth; and (10) guided travel programs to international birding destinations. Bringing Nature Home: We grow and promote 80 to 100 species of hard-to-find Maine native perennials, shrubs, trees, climate-resilient species, and more, and sell them to individuals, businesses, and municipalities throughout the State. We also maintain the Maine Native Plant Finder (https://mainenativeplants.org/).

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part III, Line 4b, Program Service Accomplishments:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: CONSERVATION: Primary conservation projects include (1) protecting nesting endangered piping plovers and least terns on the beaches of Maine; (2) working with foresters, landowners, and loggers to manage woodlands "with birds and other wildlife in mind; (3) providing outreach, education, and technical and financial resources to road professionals to help them replace malfunctioning culverts and bridges with Stream Smart crossings that improve fish and wildlife movement up, down, and along streams, and reduce risks of flooding and destruction of road infrastructure in the face of more severe storms; (4) engage anglers in a search for wild brook trout in remote ponds and coastal streams that have never been surveyed before to determine where the best, last remaining wild populations occur; (5) engage lakeshore owners, lake associations, and road associations in monitoring common loon populations, protecting water quality and loon habitat, and reducing exposure to lead fishing tackle; (6) provide training, maps, and other tools for community members to track movement of wildlife across roads to determine hot spots of activity and mortality, including a special program focused on turtles, many of whom have experienced precipitous population declines due to road collisions; and (7) produce analyses and reports on siting renewable energy projects to minimize impacts to high value species and habitats. Maine Audubon's conservation programs engage approximately 1,500 "community scientists," volunteers for the annual loon count, Stream Explorers Program, Song Meter Program, and Coastal Bird Program.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 4c, Program Service Accomplishments:
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: ADVOCACY: Maine Audubon's major current advocacy priorities include (but are not limited to): Implementing Maine's Climate Action Plan - Maine Audubon is focusing our implementation efforts on: -Increasing conservation lands in the state, with a focus on high biodiversity areas and areas important for habitat connectivity. -Improving land use planning and legal tools to emphasize smart growth and keep vital habitat intact. -Encouraging thoughtfully sited and operated renewable energy development. Advocating for renewable energy development that is sited and managed with wildlife in mind. We are advising solar developers and policy makers on smart-sited solar, producing tools to help municipalities maximize their role in smart siting, and developing policies that put best siting practices to action across the state. We're also expanding our knowledge and advocacy on offshore wind, advocating for offshore wind that is located, developed, and managed with wildlife in Maine in mind.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 10b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Two of Maine Audubon's chapters are 501(c)(3) organizations, while the other five do not have separate corporate identities. To date the organization has not developed separate written chapter policies because the relationship with the chapter includes chapter representation on the Maine Audubon Board of Trustees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The 990 will be reviewed by the members of the finance and audit committee of the Board as representatives of the Board with the skills and knowledge to fully understand the documents. They are responsible to report back to the full Board of Trustees.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each new member is given a copy of the conflict of interest policy when he/she first joins the organization or the Board. Once the new trustee or officer has been given a reasonable amount of time to review the policy, he/she signs a statement affirming that he/she has received a copy of the conflict of interest policy, has read and understands the policy, and agrees to comply with the policy. In the event any trustee or officer of the organization believes that he/she has or may have a conflict of interest or potential conflict of interest with respecet to any transactions or decision, the trustee or officer has a duty to disclose the conflict to the Board or a sub-committee of the Board responsible for overseeing the organization's compliance with the policy.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Officer compensation is set by the Governance Committee and reviewed by Executive committee of the board, and is based on compensation data obtained from the MANP salary survey as well as our own compensation study performed by KMA HR in January 2022.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The organization makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements available to the public upon request.
Consultants: Program service expenses 378,529. Management and general expenses 101,734. Fundraising expenses 22,506. Total expenses 502,769.
The process has not changed from the prior year.
